title: Ed Abbaticchio
text:
Edward James Abbaticchio (April 15, 1877 – January 6, 1957) was the first <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> player and first professional <a href="American%20football">football</a> player of <a href="Italian%20American">Italian ancestry</a>.
Baseball.
Born in <a href="Latrobe%2C%20Pennsylvania">Latrobe, Pennsylvania</a>, Abbatticchio was primarily a <a href="shortstop">shortstop</a> and <a href="second%20baseman">second baseman</a>, though he also saw playing time in the <a href="outfield">outfield</a> and at <a href="third%20base">third base</a>. He began his baseball career with a <a href="semi-professional">semi-professional</a> team from <a href="Greensburg%2C%20Pennsylvania">Greensburg, Pennsylvania</a> in . Shortly afterwards, he made his Major League debut, in the <a href="National%20League">National League</a>, on September 4, 1897 for the <a href="Philadelphia%20Phillies">Philadelphia Phillies</a>. He played in three games for the Phillies that season and played another 25 for them in . In 1899, he played in the <a href="Western%20League%20%28original%29">Western League</a> for the <a href="Minneapolis%20Millers">Minneapolis Millers</a> and in 1900 in the <a href="American%20Association%20%2819th%20century%29">American Association</a> for the Millers and the <a href="Baltimore%20Orioles">Milwaukee Brewers</a>. For the and seasons, Abbaticchio moved on to play with the <a href="Nashville%20Vols">Nashville Vols</a> of the <a href="Southern%20Association">Southern Association</a>. During those two seasons, he led the league in batting with <a href="batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">averages</a> of .360 and .367, respectively. For the next two years, he played once again in the National League for the <a href="Boston%20Beaneaters">Boston Beaneaters</a>. He had initially decided to leave baseball in , choosing instead to run a hotel in Latrobe.
A year later, the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Pirates">Pittsburgh Pirates</a> convinced Abbaticchio to join them for <a href="1907%20Pittsburgh%20Pirates%20season">their 1907 season</a>. He then stayed with Pirates until the 1910 season, when he joined the <a href="Boston%20Doves">Boston Doves</a>. During his time in Pittsburgh, Ed played on the Pirates' <a href="1909%20World%20Series">1909 World Series</a> team. However, in the World Series he struck out in his only <a href="at-bat">at-bat</a>, as a <a href="pinch%20hit">pinch hit</a>ter. However, the <a href="1908%20Pittsburgh%20Pirates%20season">season prior</a>, on October 4, Ed hit a ball into the stands in game against the <a href="Chicago%20Cubs">Chicago Cubs</a>, which was called foul by <a href="umpire">umpire</a> <a href="Hank%20O%27Day">Hank O'Day</a>, who also ruled on the infamous <a href="Merkle%27s%20Boner">Merkle's Boner</a>. The Pirates protested the call which would have been a possible <a href="home%20run">home run</a> or <a href="triple%20%28baseball%29">triple</a>, and brought the tying run to the plate. Had the Pirates won the game, they would've also captured the 1908 National League pennant. The hit eventually evolved into an <a href="urban%20legend">urban legend</a> that had Abbaticchio's foul ball striking a woman in the stands, to where she required hospital care, and which resulted in her filing a <a href="lawsuit">lawsuit</a> against the Cubs. The story of the lawsuit has since been debunked as fiction.
Abbaticchio was a good friend of Pirates great <a href="Honus%20Wagner">Honus Wagner</a>. The two played alongside each other in the Pirate infield. Wagner once called Abbaticchio a "great second baseman with whom he had the honor to play with. " Wagner also went on to say that he was "an ever lasting credit to baseball, to Pittsburgh, and his home section of Latrobe." Statistically was an above-average fielder and <a href="stolen%20bases">base thief</a>.
In 855 games over nine seasons, Abbaticchio posted a .254 <a href="batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">batting average</a> (772-for-3044) with 355 <a href="run%20%28baseball%29">runs</a>, 43 <a href="triple%20%28baseball%29">triples</a>,11 <a href="home%20runs">home runs</a>, 324 <a href="RBI">RBI</a>, 142 <a href="stolen%20bases">stolen bases</a> and 289 <a href="bases%20on%20balls">bases on balls</a>. Defensively, he recorded an overall .931 <a href="fielding%20percentage">fielding percentage</a>.
Football.
Outside of baseball, Abbatticchio was also among the first wave of professional football players. He began his professional football career with the <a href="Latrobe%20Athletic%20Association">Latrobe Athletic Association</a> in 1895 and was paid $50 a game for Latrobe. He starred as a <a href="Fullback%20%28American%20football%29">fullback</a> and <a href="Place%20kicker">kicker</a>. In 1896, Abbatticchio kicked a 23-yard kicked field goal to help give Latrobe a 5-0 win over the <a href="West%20Virginia%20Mountaineers%20football">West Virginia Mountaineers</a>. After <a href="1896%20Latrobe%20Athletic%20Association%20season">their season</a> ended, Abbatticchio and several Latrobe players such as <a href="John%20Brallier">John Brallier</a> and <a href="Harry%20Ryan%20%28American%20football%29">Harry Ryan</a> traveled to <a href="Punxsutawney%2C%20Pennsylvania">Punxsutawney, Pennsylvania</a> and played for that town's local team against a team from <a href="DuBois%2C%20Pennsylvania">DuBois</a>. The game lasted only 12 minutes before a riot ended play with Punxsutawney leading, 12-0. In 1897, Abbatticchio reportedly kicked several field goals against the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Athletic%20Club%20%28football%29">Pittsburgh Athletic Club</a>, which resulted in a 47-0 Latrobe win, and the worst defeat in the Pittsburgh Athletic Club team's history. At <a href="1897%20Latrobe%20Athletic%20Association%20season">the season's</a> end, a Pittsburgh-base football expert picked an all-western Pennsylvania team from among the area's amateur, professional, and college teams. Abbatticchio and two other Latrobe players, <a href="Tackle%20%28American%20football%20position%29">tackle</a> Harry Ryan and <a href="End%20%28American%20football%29">end</a> <a href="Walter%20Okeson">Walter Okeson</a>, were chosen to the team. On November 30, 1899, during a Thanksgiving Day game against Indiana Normal School (today <a href="Indiana%20University%20of%20Pennsylvania">Indiana University of Pennsylvania</a>), Abbaticchio was noted for his runs in a 35-0 Latrobe win. In 1900, in a two-game series against the <a href="Greensburg%20Athletic%20Association">Greensburg Athletic Association</a>, he was credited for a 23-yard game-winning field goal kick in the first game. Meanwhile, in the second game, Abbatticchio kicked 12-yard field goal, scored a touchdown, and <a href="extra%20point">kicked a goal after</a>, in an 11-0 Latrobe win.
He is credited by <a href="Fielding%20H.%20Yost">Fielding H. Yost</a> with developing the first spiral <a href="Punt%20%28gridiron%20football%29">punt</a>, enabling the ball to travel farther.
He died in <a href="Fort%20Lauderdale%2C%20Florida">Fort Lauderdale, Florida</a> in 1957.
